blog.title: Iron Dad All Day Every Day
blog.description: Tony Stark, Steve Rogers and Peter Parker have taken over my life. I write stories and then cry over them.

summary: IronDad and SLEEPY PETER 😊
question: IronDad and SLEEPY PETER 😊
answer:
HI babe! I hope you like this <3

-First, a sleepy Peter is an adorable Peter and it doesn’t take long for Tony to realize this.

-Whenever Peter sleeps, his curls just flop onto his face and Tony always reaches out to brush his curls away and then he just spends minutes running his fingers through Peter’s hair

-Somehow in his sleep, Peter looks even younger, like years younger and Tony just watches him and wonders what life would be like now if he met Peter earlier on (probably a lot less emotional trauma)

-Peter can’t sleep unless it’s cold and he’s covered under a million blankets

-”Kid, isn’t it better just to turn up the thermo-”

-”Nope.” Peter cuts him off from his blanket cocoon.

-Tony just shakes his head and presses a kiss to Peter’s forehead

-Peter SNORES but it’s not a loud snore that wakes up everyone within a ten-mile radius it’s a soft snore, more like a purr than a snore

-Catch Peter sleeping with Iron Man pajamas. The first time he slept over at the tower and stumbled into the kitchen, Tony was grinning like an idiot at the kid’s pajamas.

-Best thing ever is a sleepy Peter during movie night. Peter never fails to curl up against Tony and fall asleep when watching a movie and Tony loves is. He can wrap his arms around Peter and bring him close, pressing his nose into the kid’s curls.

-The worst thing is a sleepy, lethargic Peter who’s trying to fight off a cold. He’s wheezy, coughing, sniffling and just downright miserable. He can’t lay down and sleep because the coughing is worse so Tony helps him by sitting up in his bed and has Peter rest against him. It breaks his back because he’s like that all night but as long as Peter gets rest it doesn’t matter

summary: I don't really care about what will happend in A4. The think I really care about and I need Marvel to give us is: The 5 years...
body:
I don’t really care about what will happend in A4. The think I really care about and I need Marvel to give us is: The 5 years after the snap.  Even if it means Ned and MJ graduating without Peter.  Even if it means Shury ruling Wakanda without her big brother by her side, Even if it means Tony blaming himself for what has happened. And not stoping after being assured like million times that its not his fault. And even if it means Thor being extremely sad about Loki’s death. Or Rocket being without his “family” for that long time.

Because after that I need Marvel to give us time right after A4. To give us Peter hugging his friends again, swaering that he will never leave them. To give us Peter Quill meeting Gamora and being sorry about what he did. To give us Steve speaking with Bucky again.  To give us Thor almost crying that his beloved brother is back, telling him, he will never let him die again. To give us Mr. Stark having baby with Pepper and finally stop having his nightmares and anxiety attack. And finally I need Marvel to give us Dr. Strange watching this from distance, smiling happily about the fact that he was right all the time.

Because my lovely characters showing out the emotions is more worth it than whole how-to-actually-kill-thanos-concept (A4) and all the heroic scenes in it.

summary: Congrats on the 500!! That's awesome and you deserve so many more! Can you do the prompt Black Friday and either?
question: Congrats on the 500!! That's awesome and you deserve so many more! Can you do the prompt Black Friday and either?
answer:
Let’s do superfamily with this one! :D


-Tony and Peter, for some reason that Steve cannot grasp his mind around, love Black Friday.

-Don’t get Steve wrong, he loves a good sale because even with marrying a billionaire, he doesn’t like to spend a lot of money on frivolous things (except when it comes to Peter because that’s his baby boy and he’ll spoil him if he wants). But there’s no reason to cut Thanksgiving dinner short to go to the stores.

-”You guys do realize we’re not actually strapped for money, right? Right?”

-”Babe, this isn’t for the sales. It’s for the chaos. Middle-class white suburbans moms throwing it down with each other in the middle of Target. Sign me the fuck up.”

-Tony tells him with an evil grin and his teenage son follows suit with an actually matching evil, but adorable grin (the fact that he’s bundled up in about a hundred layers helps with this look) and Steve prays for their souls.

-Tony gets Happy to drive them nearly an hour away to the most popular Target and drop them off. They’re already a massive crowd huddled near the doors waiting for them to open. A few fights have already broken out if anything was to be said about the numerous cop cars and cops around.

-”This is gonna be so much fun,” Tony says gleefully, rubbing his hands together.

-Steve gives his a husband a bewildered look before wrapping a protective arm around Peter and bringing him close.

-The doors open and Steve grabs a hold of Tony’s hoodie and pulls him back before he can join the sea of white moms. 

-Tony pouts.

-Once they get in Steve pretty much all but carries Peter around, not trusting a single person in this store, including his husband.

-”Pops, I’m fifteen, please put me down. I’m not a baby.”

-”Nope.” Steve all but says watching a woman climb onto a shelf and throw herself into a sea of people in order to grab a crockpot that was on sale.

-Peter - :(

-They lose sight of Tony so they have to walk around trying to find him. Finally, Steve gives up and just goes to the grocery area where it’s completely empty. So he just grabs a cart and legit starts grocery shopping.

-He sends a text to Tony that’s if he’s still alive here’s where to find them.

tags: aka steve rogers is a bamf
summary: better man
title: better man
body:
it’s press conference day. steve hates press conference day. all the lights, flashing, and the clamoring and the sounds, the yelling, the pushing, the desperation. steve hates it. 

so do the rest of the avengers. bruce is probably the only one who hates it more than he does. tony and natasha, they’re good. they’re great. by the time they’ve finished their answers, you’ve managed to forget what you’ve asked in the first place.

but steve especially hates press conference day after a week like this. a week where a couple gets killed because they miscalculated, because of mistakes and fate and inevitability. you can’t save them all. 

so, when a young, hipster looking reporter stands up and asks tony “is there any reason for the deaths reported in Aheia on wednesday? was it your recklessness or a miscalculation on someone else’s part?” steve groans internally.

tony sighs and brings his hand up to his face. steve’s jaw clenches and his hands form fists under the table, but he stays quiet. tony can handle this. but the reporter doesn’t stop.

“there were first hand accounts that stated that you made a choice not to protect those civilians, resulting in their deaths. can you explain that, mr. stark? was it your choice to let those people die?”

the reporter looks happy, exuberant, at the results his words are having. natasha is glaring at him, and if there wasn’t 500 cameras on them, steve’s pretty sure the guy would be dead by now. even bruce looks like he wants to throttle the guy, his fingers unconsciously trying to drill a hole in the table.

tony sighs again, and steve can see the toll the words are having on him. that’s when steve decides enough is enough.

“hey listen here, buddy,” he says, with ice and venom in his voice, “my husband is a fucking hero. a hero. he was smarter and stronger than you the moment he was born. he went through more pain and trauma in three months than you’ve ever had in your entire miserable life. he chose to be iron man. he chooses to protect people. and please, show me these so called “first hand accounts” that my husband chose to let those people die. the truth is, buddy, that if a bomb were to land in this room right now and there was the choice between saving his own life and saving yours, he’d save yours. that’s the kind of man my husband is. that’s the kind of choice he’d make,” steve says, finishing with a near growl. 

tony is looking at him with a bit of admiration and a fair bit of love in his eyes, whereas bruce and thor both look slightly amazed. they’ve all stood up and started to leave, the reporters still in stunned silence, when steve turns back around, marching back to the reporter.

“what’s your name?” he asks, eyes fixed.

“michael?” the man squeaks out, his eyes wide.

“just for the record, michael. you’re officially on my bad side. you can ask all the people who’ve ended up on my bad side how that went for them. actually, wait, no, you can’t, because they’re dead.”

michael shudders at that, steve’s finger in his chest. 

when steve finally marches back where the press can’t see them, tony catches him off guard and kisses him breathless. 

“that,” tony says, breathing deeply, “was one of the hottest things i’ve ever seen.”

steve grins at his husband. “i meant every word,” he says, sincerely. 

tony rolls his eyes and pulls him back in again. “thank you,” he whispers when they finally break apart.

steve just grabs his hand and squeezes. no one talks to his husband like that.

tony is looking at him with a bit of admiration and a fair bit of love in his eyes, whereas bruce and thor both look slightly amazed. they’ve all stood up and started to leave, the reporters still in stunned silence, when steve turns back around, marching back to the reporter.

“what’s your name?” he asks, eyes fixed.

“michael?” the man squeaks out, his eyes wide.

“just for the record, michael. you’re officially on my bad side. you can ask all the people who’ve ended up on my bad side how that went for them. actually, wait, no, you can’t, because they’re dead.”

michael shudders at that, steve’s finger in his chest. 

when steve finally marches back where the press can’t see them, tony catches him off guard and kisses him breathless. 

“that,” tony says, breathing deeply, “was one of the hottest things i’ve ever seen.”

steve grins at his husband. “i meant every word,” he says, sincerely. 

tony rolls his eyes and pulls him back in again. “thank you,” he whispers when they finally break apart.

steve just grabs his hand and squeezes. no one talks to his husband like that.

trail.content_raw:
it’s press conference day. steve hates press conference day. all the lights, flashing, and the clamoring and the sounds, the yelling, the pushing, the desperation. steve hates it. 

so do the rest of the avengers. bruce is probably the only one who hates it more than he does. tony and natasha, they’re good. they’re great. by the time they’ve finished their answers, you’ve managed to forget what you’ve asked in the first place.

but steve especially hates press conference day after a week like this. a week where a couple gets killed because they miscalculated, because of mistakes and fate and inevitability. you can’t save them all. 

so, when a young, hipster looking reporter stands up and asks tony “is there any reason for the deaths reported in Aheia on wednesday? was it your recklessness or a miscalculation on someone else’s part?” steve groans internally.

tony sighs and brings his hand up to his face. steve’s jaw clenches and his hands form fists under the table, but he stays quiet. tony can handle this. but the reporter doesn’t stop.

“there were first hand accounts that stated that you made a choice not to protect those civilians, resulting in their deaths. can you explain that, mr. stark? was it your choice to let those people die?”

the reporter looks happy, exuberant, at the results his words are having. natasha is glaring at him, and if there wasn’t 500 cameras on them, steve’s pretty sure the guy would be dead by now. even bruce looks like he wants to throttle the guy, his fingers unconsciously trying to drill a hole in the table.

MASTERPOST

summary: Chamomile, Lavender, Vetiver, and Cedarwood
title: Chamomile, Lavender, Vetiver, and Cedarwood
body:
fandom: Stony (Steve x Tony), MCU

summary: After a long, tiring week Steve falls asleep on Tony and Tony takes it on himself to put his soldier to rest and at ease.

length: 973 words

a/n: I dedicate this fic to my tumblr daughter @priness-evans-addict  - I saw you were going through some rough weeks and I wanted to write something for you - it is just a small fic, but I hope it will make you feel calmer and comforted ♥

——————–

Chamomile, Lavender, Vetiver, and Cedarwood

“Oof.”

Tony grunted quietly, when a heavy super soldier slid on him, completely limp, almost smothering him into the couch. Just a few minutes ago, Steve was wide awake, stuffing handfuls of colorful button-shaped chocolates in his mouth, and when the sugar high ended, he had fallen asleep, minutes after the movie started.

“Hey, Steve,” Tony said in a low whisper, slowly maneuvering his sleeping boyfriend’s body and untangling himself from the super soldier death trap.  Steve was completely motionless, his head rolled to the back and his chest rhythmically raising up and down. Out as a light, heavy as a log. “Okay, big guy, time for bed,” Tony decided, standing up and pulling his boyfriend up.

“M'fine…” Steve replied in his half-awake state and Tony resorted to a courteous eye roll. Casablanca playing on the TV, binging on m&ms…  When Steve proposed a movie night, Tony agreed, always up to spending some time with his boyfriend, even if the mood of the evening was nostalgia, it was important to share such moments together. The moment ended when half of the involved party fell asleep.

“Of course you are,” Tony agreed halfheartedly, putting more strength into it and after some efforts, he managed to pull Steve up and slung the soldier’s arm around his shoulders for more support. “Come on, baby, walk with me,” he urged, tapping his bare foot against Steve’s socked one, snorting when Steve mumbled something about dancing and having two left feet.

Slowly, step by step, they reached their shared bedroom, Tony asking Friday appropriately earlier to prepare everything and when they walked into the room, it was already nicely dim and cozy and in just the right temperature and level of humidity for a good night of sleep.

“You need to brush your teeth,” Tony reminded, squeezing Steve closer when his boyfriend almost tumbled on the bed.

“Can’t get cavity,” Steve bargained, making some longing sounds and reaching his hand for the bed. He just wanted to lay down already.

“Come on, brush your teeth and I will give you a nice goodnight kiss,” Tony gave an offer on his own, humming out the words enticingly and patting Steve’s chest to make him a bit more awake. It did happen that Tony himself fell to sleep numerous times as he was standing, often in clothes reeking of car grease and sweat, but he always brushed his teeth - waking up and feeling that unpleasant dryness and an aftertaste reminding him of chewed shoes, was never fun.

More groaning, more sleepy whimpering, but in the end, Steve obediently walked to the en-suite bathroom to get some basic evening rituals done. Tony continued his work with making their bedroom extra cozy, knowing how hard the passing week was on his boyfriend. Debriefings, meetings, negotiations - seemed that each time Steve had left the conference room, he had to run straight back into it. Put him on the battlefield and make him fight - it was his element, it was draining for sure, but not as psychically exhausting as countless hours of talks and drafts. Tony opened the drawer in the nightstand table on his side of the bed and took out his secret weapon, a homemade mix of essentials oils and some distilled water in a spray bottle. He fluffed Steve’s pillow a few times before giving the material a few puffs. Chamomile, lavender, vetiver, and cedarwood. Herbal, sweet, earthy and woody. The calming, warm scent would guarantee some good dreams.

There was a sound of the door closing, and Tony smiled at his fumbling soldier. Steve walked to him, keeping his eyes half closed and there was something endearing about watching the usually alert and collected man so drowsy and almost helpless.

“Arms up,” Tony ordered, sitting Steve on the bed, and pulling his shirt off when the soldier obeyed. Then trousers and socks. Even underwear as it was warm enough for Steve to sleep completely nude. After putting the clothes aside, Tony pushed his boyfriend down gently and Steve listened, lowering his face into the pillow and breathing in the sweet scent of essential oils.

“Get some rest,” Tony said, tucking the blanket around Steve’s body. When he started to wrap the material around his feet, Steve kicked his legs, laughing a bit.

“Nooo, too hot,” came the first protest of the evening, and Tony smiled, registering the small laugh and sensing that it wasn’t the reason. Being the amazing and caring boyfriend he was, Tony doubled his efforts.

“I have to tuck you in!”

“Nooo, To-ony!”

“What if some monster will come and grab your leg?! This is for your own safety!” Tony justified himself, trying to tame the restless feet, his fingers brushing Steve’s soles playfully, adding to soldier’s laughter. It went on for a bit, but Tony didn’t want to bother his boyfriend too much and gave up after a while with an exaggerated huff.

“Fine, fine,” Tony said in a light voice, ceasing his efforts and moving away, letting Steve place his legs in any way he wanted. “Don’t blame me if you stick your feet out during the night and wake up without them.”

There was no answer, just another small laugh. Tony couldn’t help but smile.

“Goodnight, hun,” Tony leaned down and placed a lingering kiss on Steve’s warm cheek, smelling in the herbs and flowers and mint from the toothpaste. Steve hummed his goodnight, his eyes finally closing to sleep. Tony stayed for a bit longer, combing his fingers through the blond hair and just taking in the moment. It wasn’t the romantic evening he counted for, but this was sweet too.

Until Steve started to snore like a chainsaw and Tony had to evacuate himself out of the bedroom. Sleeping Steve was cute, but snoring one not so much.

More groaning, more sleepy whimpering, but in the end, Steve obediently walked to the en-suite bathroom to get some basic evening rituals done. Tony continued his work with making their bedroom extra cozy, knowing how hard the passing week was on his boyfriend. Debriefings, meetings, negotiations - seemed that each time Steve had left the conference room, he had to run straight back into it. Put him on the battlefield and make him fight - it was his element, it was draining for sure, but not as psychically exhausting as countless hours of talks and drafts. Tony opened the drawer in the nightstand table on his side of the bed and took out his secret weapon, a homemade mix of essentials oils and some distilled water in a spray bottle. He fluffed Steve’s pillow a few times before giving the material a few puffs. Chamomile, lavender, vetiver, and cedarwood. Herbal, sweet, earthy and woody. The calming, warm scent would guarantee some good dreams.

There was a sound of the door closing, and Tony smiled at his fumbling soldier. Steve walked to him, keeping his eyes half closed and there was something endearing about watching the usually alert and collected man so drowsy and almost helpless.

“Arms up,” Tony ordered, sitting Steve on the bed, and pulling his shirt off when the soldier obeyed. Then trousers and socks. Even underwear as it was warm enough for Steve to sleep completely nude. After putting the clothes aside, Tony pushed his boyfriend down gently and Steve listened, lowering his face into the pillow and breathing in the sweet scent of essential oils.

“Get some rest,” Tony said, tucking the blanket around Steve’s body. When he started to wrap the material around his feet, Steve kicked his legs, laughing a bit.

“Nooo, too hot,” came the first protest of the evening, and Tony smiled, registering the small laugh and sensing that it wasn’t the reason. Being the amazing and caring boyfriend he was, Tony doubled his efforts.

“I have to tuck you in!”

“Nooo, To-ony!”

“What if some monster will come and grab your leg?! This is for your own safety!” Tony justified himself, trying to tame the restless feet, his fingers brushing Steve’s soles playfully, adding to soldier’s laughter. It went on for a bit, but Tony didn’t want to bother his boyfriend too much and gave up after a while with an exaggerated huff.

“Fine, fine,” Tony said in a light voice, ceasing his efforts and moving away, letting Steve place his legs in any way he wanted. “Don’t blame me if you stick your feet out during the night and wake up without them.”

There was no answer, just another small laugh. Tony couldn’t help but smile.

“Goodnight, hun,” Tony leaned down and placed a lingering kiss on Steve’s warm cheek, smelling in the herbs and flowers and mint from the toothpaste. Steve hummed his goodnight, his eyes finally closing to sleep. Tony stayed for a bit longer, combing his fingers through the blond hair and just taking in the moment. It wasn’t the romantic evening he counted for, but this was sweet too.

Until Steve started to snore like a chainsaw and Tony had to evacuate himself out of the bedroom. Sleeping Steve was cute, but snoring one not so much.

summary: After a long, tiring week Steve falls asleep on Tony and Tony takes it on himself to put his soldier to rest and at ease.

length: 973 words

a/n: I dedicate this fic to my tumblr daughter @priness-evans-addict  - I saw you were going through some rough weeks and I wanted to write something for you - it is just a small fic, but I hope it will make you feel calmer and comforted ♥

——————–

Chamomile, Lavender, Vetiver, and Cedarwood

“Oof.”

Tony grunted quietly, when a heavy super soldier slid on him, completely limp, almost smothering him into the couch. Just a few minutes ago, Steve was wide awake, stuffing handfuls of colorful button-shaped chocolates in his mouth, and when the sugar high ended, he had fallen asleep, minutes after the movie started.

“Hey, Steve,” Tony said in a low whisper, slowly maneuvering his sleeping boyfriend’s body and untangling himself from the super soldier death trap.  Steve was completely motionless, his head rolled to the back and his chest rhythmically raising up and down. Out as a light, heavy as a log. “Okay, big guy, time for bed,” Tony decided, standing up and pulling his boyfriend up.

body:
Fic: Provide Me        
archiveofourown.org/works/16441238/chapters/38498054

Fandom: Marvel

Relationships: Steve Rogers & Tony Stark, Steve Rogers & Natasha Romanov, Basically All the Avengers With Each Other

Summary: Tony wakes up a lot younger than he’s supposed to be. The team try to figure out how to handle this.
Tension headaches, a little heartache, and a lot of learning ensues.

This week: Tony is introduced to Sam, and everyone tries to calm each other down!

Excerpt from Chapter 5:

“You want to know what this does?” he asked. Tony nodded. “Well, if you press some of these buttons, then – actually, it will seem much more impressive if I show you. Uh … Karen, could you show Tony how awesome my suit is?” A small hologram dropped down, showing Sam in the full armored suit and goggles. Suddenly, huge metal wings shot out from the backpack. Within seconds Sam was off the ground, whistling through the air and, if Tony was hearing correctly, whooping.

“Wow,” he said softly. Sam grinned.

“Bad-ass, right?”

“Can everyone fly?”

Sam laughed. “Just the cool people.”

“What lies are you filling his head with?” Natasha said, returning without the pizza.

“Just letting him know how things work around here.”

“Oh? You let him know I knocked you out the sky last week with one good throw?”

“Hey, you can’t let me have one thing?” Sam complained. “And anyway, Tony, you and I are fixing that. We’re going to take her next time.”

“I really work on this?” Tony said, in wonder. Surely, with a building like this, they could afford someone better than him.

“Yeah! Though you’re not allowed to fly it, no matter how many times you ask.” Sam opened a small panel that Tony hadn’t noticed, and typed in a code. Several panels rose up and out of the backpack, revealing some wiring and inner machinery. “You want to see how it works?” Tony looked at Natasha. She raised her eyebrows and nodded. He nodded at Sam. “Cool! Now I understand, like, thirty percent of this, so you might have to help me with some of it …”

An hour later, Sam and Tony were sat on the floor, knee-deep in blue projections (after needing heavy intervention from Karen to reassemble the exterior of a wing, they’d decided hypothetical tinkering was safer). Tony was … having fun. There was no deadline, it really didn’t seem like they cared what he made, or even if he made any progress. In some ways, it was more relaxed than home. He just wished Jarvis was here. Then Natasha returned, holding some folded plaid pajamas.

“Time for bed, Tony. Looks like you boys are having fun, but we’re trying to be responsible guardians, here.” Sam reached to the ceiling and rolled his shoulders back, letting out a groan.

“Man, I’m tired. Save our stuff, will you, J- Karen?”

“Of course, Sam.” The images disappeared. Sam pushed himself to his feet, and held out a hand to Tony.

“Come on, let’s get you to bed.” Tony accepted the hand to pull himself up, and walked with Sam and Natasha back to his room. They were talking in low voices about spider bites, for some reason. He hoped there weren’t dangerous spiders in future-New-York.

Natasha gave him the pajamas to change into. Looking in the bathroom mirror, Tony tried to imagine his face, forty years older. He didn’t understand why he’d grow a beard like that. Taking his shirt off, he saw that the purple bruising along his ribs had faded to a brownish yellow. The swelling on his fore-arm was barely noticeable, now. Thankfully, the shirt Natasha had given him was a button-down.

When he came back into his room, Sam had something small and green in his hand. He held it out, and Tony realized it was a plushie, but a very strange one; it looked like Frankenstein’s monster in shorts.

“This is our friend Bruce. You’ll meet him tomorrow. Sometimes he worries that he’s scary, but you’ve got to remember, he’s just a softie really.” Natasha was hiding her mouth behind her hand.

“Your friend’s green?” Tony wasn’t sure what he wouldn’t believe, at this point.

“Hopefully not when you see him,” Sam said, motioning for Tony to take the toy.

“I don’t need a toy,” Tony said uncertainly. He didn’t understand why they seemed so willing to let him waste his time with baby stuff.

“No, of course not,” Sam frowned. “But my niece has one just like this, only of our other friend, Clint. And she’s a year older than you. I suppose I could give it to her, if you don’t want it …”

“No,” Tony said, reaching out to take it. “If she has one, then I suppose that – that’s fine.”

“Great,” Sam said, smiling. “He’s called Hulk.”

“I’m sorry, sir, it’s just that they had complaints about the quality and-”

“Isn’t it funny how I don’t care?” mused Tony, cutting off the stuttering man in front of him. “Don’t you find that funny, Peter?”

Peter pulled his mouth off Tony’s cock, offering his boyfriend an impish smile as he kept pumping his shaft, using his spit to slick the way. “Hilarious, daddy.”

“Sir, it’s really not my fault that-”

“I don’t really think I’ve made myself clear, here.” said Tony, one hand going to push Peter’s head back down onto his dick, the other reaching to pick up the hand gun lying on the table. “I said that I don’t fucking care.”

“Please, sir, I have a daughter, she’s only a baby-”

“Not my problem, dear.” drawled Tony, cocking the gun in his hand. “You assured me you had a reliable buyer, and I really don’t like when people lie to me.”

The man in front of Tony paled, keeping his mouth shut as Peter pulled off Tony’s dick, sliding up to sit on his lap, grinding his hips lazily. At once, Tony’s arms were wrapped around his waist as he mouthed at the boy’s neck.

“I don’t think you should kill him, daddy.” Peter said, tilting his head to allow for better access.

“He’s causing daddy a lot of problems, angel.”

“But his girlfriend makes the most amazing apple pies, daddy. If she’s sad, then maybe she won’t make them anymore.”

“Angel.”

“Daddy, please.” whined Peter, widening his eyes at the older man, eyelashes fluttering. “Pretty please?”

Tony sighed in frustration, beckoning the man closer to him. Once he was within arm’s length, Tony backhanded him across the face with the harsh metal of his gun, sending the man to the floor, blood streaming from his nose. Tony offered the bouncers by the door a signal, and they were by the table immediately, hauling the semi-unconscious thug to his feet.

“Thank your wife, asshole.” Tony called after him. “She just saved your fucking life.”

As the bouncers disappeared, Peter licked a stripe up Tony’s neck, causing the older man to shudder and grab his hips.

“Opened myself for you, daddy.” panted Peter. “Please may I ride you?”

“Be my guest, princess.”

Tony sighed in frustration, beckoning the man closer to him. Once he was within arm’s length, Tony backhanded him across the face with the harsh metal of his gun, sending the man to the floor, blood streaming from his nose. Tony offered the bouncers by the door a signal, and they were by the table immediately, hauling the semi-unconscious thug to his feet.

“Thank your wife, asshole.” Tony called after him. “She just saved your fucking life.”

As the bouncers disappeared, Peter licked a stripe up Tony’s neck, causing the older man to shudder and grab his hips.

“Opened myself for you, daddy.” panted Peter. “Please may I ride you?”

“Be my guest, princess.”

Worshipping Cap through the written word.

summary: Preview: “Resistance” chapter 27
title: Preview: “Resistance” chapter 27
body:
“Steven?”

              Steve ripped around to find Thor behind him.  Seeing their friend in this cramped space, ducking to get inside the area but coming closer so carefully, watching him with worried blue eyes and keeping his distance like he was afraid he might spook an injured animal…  Steve sucked in a shaking breath and wiped wildly at his cheeks.  It took an incredible amount of determination but he calmed himself, too ashamed to do anything else.  He pushed a hand through his hair and hauled in breath after breath until the tiny, shadowy nook stopped spinning and he could focus beyond his skin crawling and his pulse drumming in his ears.

              After what felt like forever, Thor quietly asked, “Are you well, my friend?”

              That was a stupid question.  Steve managed to gather himself more, nodding vigorously before he actually managed to speak. “’m fine,” he mumbled.  The weight of Thor’s gaze felt damning, and he turned before he thought better of it.  He supposed it made sense for Thor to be staring at him as he was, scrutinizing him, but all he could glimpse in the other man’s eyes was grief.  And worry.  And pity.  Steve took another breath, turning back to the shadows.  “I’m fine.  Everythin’s fine.”

              “It does not seem to be.”  Steve felt more than saw Thor take a step closer.  “Nor does it need to be.”

              Steve closed his eyes helplessly.  How could he be so deluded to think he could hide anything?  “We’ll be okay.”  His voice was hardly anything.

              Thor didn’t answer right away, and when he did, the words hurt.  “In time,” he offered quietly, “and with help.  You seem very little like the man I knew four months ago.”  Hearing someone else say that was beyond painful.  In a way, as stressful as it had been being surrounded by these strangers, that had been a shield of sorts, too.  These people, whether it be the Guardians or the Nova Corpsmen or the Xandarian doctors, had never known them before Hell.  They couldn’t see the contrast, so it wasn’t so obvious what had been changed.  What had been lost and damaged.

              Being with Thor was direct evidence of all of that.  The last time Steve had talked to the God of Thunder had been right before the battle where he and Tony had been kidnapped.  Thor had been bickering with Barton over some movie they’d watched, and he’d wanted Steve’s opinion (and for that opinion to match his, of course).  Steve hadn’t ever seen the movie in question, but Thor had been loud and affectionate and cajoling, and they’d all laughed like good buddies.  That had been four months ago.

              Four months.  Four months since they’d been kidnapped.  Four months since they’d been to Earth, to New York.  Four months since he’d been Captain America. In reality, that wasn’t much time at all, but in the pit?  In Hell? The days had gone on and on.  A lifetime of them had passed painfully slowly, moment by moment with so much darkness and so little hope.  “Not sure that I am,” he whispered.

              To that Thor said nothing at first, and the hum of the ship was very loud. Steve could almost hear Tony softly and evenly breathing where the other man still slumbered in the bunk.  At least he’s asleep.  He’s still sleeping.  Steve shivered in relief, rubbing his arms through his shirt and bristling anew at how unpleasant his own touch was.  It was constant, this tickling under his skin like an itch he could never scratch, throbbing in his muscles like pain he couldn’t massage away.  Tears stung his eyes again.  God, he was pathetic.

              Thor sighed.  “I don’t know the particulars of what happened.  I doubt anyone does, aside from you and Stark.  Still, I was told enough about your captivity that my imagination has no difficulty in providing the details.”  Steve closed his eyes tighter. “There is a reason that prisoners of the Kree rarely live to relay their tale.  I can see it you both, signs of the deepest suffering, and I am sorry, truly sorry, that I was not able to find you time.”  Thor’s tone grew taut with anger.  “My father…  He would not permit me to use Asgard’s resources to search for you.  When it became obvious Earthen forces were not going to be nearly sufficient, I returned home and beseeched him for aid. He gave me none and forbid me to spend my time trying to find you.  I defied him, of course, but I wasted precious weeks, and without Heimdall’s aid…” Steve vaguely knew who that was. Thor had mentioned him once or twice before.  Heimdall was his dear friend, the guardian of the Bifrost, someone with the powerful, magical capability of seeing every soul in the galaxy.   If Thor had had his help, if he’d been able to find them right away, before they’d been sold at the slave auction and brought to the moon…

              “I am sorry,” Thor murmured again.

              Steve opened his eyes.  He didn’t turn around.  He didn’t even absolve Thor.  He probably should have, but he just didn’t have the strength.  “Doesn’t matter now,” he finally said as the silence dragged on. That seemed so cruel, so final, and despite all the pain…  He just couldn’t leave it that way.  “We’re lucky you found us.  Lucky to be alive.”

              “It is not luck that allowed you to survive.”  To be honest, Steve didn’t want to hear this.  He knew what Thor was going to say, and he didn’t want someone consoling him or telling him how strong and brave they had been to live through what they had.  Maybe that was petty, because he’d always believed in comforting those who needed it, and he definitely needed it.  It was that optimism that Tony had so often detested down in the pit, that belief that fundamentally things were alright and people were decent and deserved a fair shake.  That an individual had the power to live a good life and do the right thing no matter what.  Those beliefs had survived the worst horrors of humanity during the war.

              But he hadn’t lived that depravity in a sense. Sure, he’d seen it.  He’d fought against it.  He’d experienced it.  And, as a soldier, he’d thought he understood it.  But he hadn’t.  He hadn’t been immersed in it with no escape.  He hadn’t watched people tearing other people apart for a morsel of food or a scrap of clothing or for no reason at all other than anger, sport, and bloodlust.  He hadn’t been tortured, hadn’t nearly been starved to death, hadn’t lived in filth and his own blood, hadn’t been treated as nothing more than a slab of meat and made to work until he died.  He hadn’t had to watch someone he cared for deeply fall into depression and desperation, hadn’t had to see him suffer with guilt, hadn’t known at all what that was like. It fucking hurt.

              So he didn’t care about the platitudes he figured Thor was going to offer.  It was empty solace spoken by someone who had no idea what it was like to live like an animal, to cling to your humanity in a grimy pit of violence and misery where everything was reduced to its basest and worst form.  Thor had no goddamn clue.

              Thor was more perceptive that anyone gave him credit for, though.  “It is not my place to tell you how to feel. Surely coming back to us after what happened to you is jarring, to say the least.  But I am certain you will find no relief in solitude.”

              Anger and pain rushed over Steve in a tidal wave, and he turned to glare at his teammate.  Thor shook his head and raised his hands in a nonthreatening show.  “I mean no insult.  It’s merely an observation.  Stark… He is far from who he was as well, but at least he seems to take solace in you.  In being close to you.”  The corner of Thor’s mouth turned upward in a small, rueful grin.  “That’s fairly surprising, considering how poorly you two got along before you were lost.  You were hardly friends.”  He considered that a moment.  “Though I suppose it’s not surprising, actually, when you think about it. Traumatic circumstances have been known to bond people together.”

              Is that what had happened?  Considering the mess of everything, Steve wasn’t certain.  His memories of their escape attempt were hazy at best.  He could recall being stuck in that dark shard elevator as they’d been brought back down to Hell.  He remembered Tony asking him, no, begging him to kill them both…  Obviously he hadn’t done it.  He was pretty sure he’d told Tony he loved him, and he was pretty sure Tony had said he loved him back.  Didn’t that mean something more than a bond born from traumatic circumstances?  Tony had meant it, didn’t he?  Steve had.  He’d meant it with his whole heart.  Their experiences together in Hell hadn’t simply birthed their relationship.  It had shown them both what had been there all along, what could have been if they’d just looked and given each other the chance.

              Right?

              Thor sighed again.  “I’ve seen you pull away from him numerous times since I arrived.  Like now.  He has been at your side constantly, but you’ve flinched and withdrawn.  And it’s not my place to say…  I realize it’s not.  But I fear for you and for him.  It’s clear he needs you.”

              “I know he does,” Steve said, turning away again.

              “And you need him.  So why…”

              Steve grimaced and dug his fingers into his arm until the pain was nearly unbearable.  He didn’t want to talk about it.  He really didn’t.  But he’d kept the pain inside for days and days, ever since he’d become aware enough to realize how much he couldn’t stand to be touched, ever since the venomous teeth of what this meant had dug into this heart and spread their poison.  It was impossible to ignore or hide it now.  “I can’t…”  His voice failed him, and he shivered, looking down and trying to gather himself.  “I can’t stand having him close.”

              “Why?”  That was asked without judgment.

              Steve glanced over his shoulder at Tony, who hadn’t moved at all.  Who was still sleeping.  And, God, he wanted to go back to bed with him.  He was still so tired, as if the fatigue had settled deep into his organs and bones and couldn’t be expunged no matter how much sleep he got. But the thought of Tony holding onto him, of the nightmares gleefully hissing and dancing on edge of his consciousness…  “It hurts,” he confessed.  “It hurts so much.”

Catch up on AO3!

That seemed so cruel, so final, and despite all the pain…  He just couldn’t leave it that way.  “We’re lucky you found us.  Lucky to be alive.”

              “It is not luck that allowed you to survive.”  To be honest, Steve didn’t want to hear this.  He knew what Thor was going to say, and he didn’t want someone consoling him or telling him how strong and brave they had been to live through what they had.  Maybe that was petty, because he’d always believed in comforting those who needed it, and he definitely needed it.  It was that optimism that Tony had so often detested down in the pit, that belief that fundamentally things were alright and people were decent and deserved a fair shake.  That an individual had the power to live a good life and do the right thing no matter what.  Those beliefs had survived the worst horrors of humanity during the war.

              But he hadn’t lived that depravity in a sense. Sure, he’d seen it.  He’d fought against it.  He’d experienced it.  And, as a soldier, he’d thought he understood it.  But he hadn’t.  He hadn’t been immersed in it with no escape.  He hadn’t watched people tearing other people apart for a morsel of food or a scrap of clothing or for no reason at all other than anger, sport, and bloodlust.  He hadn’t been tortured, hadn’t nearly been starved to death, hadn’t lived in filth and his own blood, hadn’t been treated as nothing more than a slab of meat and made to work until he died.  He hadn’t had to watch someone he cared for deeply fall into depression and desperation, hadn’t had to see him suffer with guilt, hadn’t known at all what that was like. It fucking hurt.

              So he didn’t care about the platitudes he figured Thor was going to offer.  It was empty solace spoken by someone who had no idea what it was like to live like an animal, to cling to your humanity in a grimy pit of violence and misery where everything was reduced to its basest and worst form.  Thor had no goddamn clue.

              Thor was more perceptive that anyone gave him credit for, though.  “It is not my place to tell you how to feel. Surely coming back to us after what happened to you is jarring, to say the least.  But I am certain you will find no relief in solitude.”

              Anger and pain rushed over Steve in a tidal wave, and he turned to glare at his teammate.  Thor shook his head and raised his hands in a nonthreatening show.  “I mean no insult.  It’s merely an observation.  Stark… He is far from who he was as well, but at least he seems to take solace in you.  In being close to you.”  The corner of Thor’s mouth turned upward in a small, rueful grin.  “That’s fairly surprising, considering how poorly you two got along before you were lost.  You were hardly friends.”  He considered that a moment.  “Though I suppose it’s not surprising, actually, when you think about it. Traumatic circumstances have been known to bond people together.”

              Is that what had happened?  Considering the mess of everything, Steve wasn’t certain.  His memories of their escape attempt were hazy at best.  He could recall being stuck in that dark shard elevator as they’d been brought back down to Hell.  He remembered Tony asking him, no, begging him to kill them both…  Obviously he hadn’t done it.  He was pretty sure he’d told Tony he loved him, and he was pretty sure Tony had said he loved him back.  Didn’t that mean something more than a bond born from traumatic circumstances?  Tony had meant it, didn’t he?  Steve had.  He’d meant it with his whole heart.  Their experiences together in Hell hadn’t simply birthed their relationship.  It had shown them both what had been there all along, what could have been if they’d just looked and given each other the chance.

              Right?

              Thor sighed again.  “I’ve seen you pull away from him numerous times since I arrived.  Like now.  He has been at your side constantly, but you’ve flinched and withdrawn.  And it’s not my place to say…  I realize it’s not.  But I fear for you and for him.  It’s clear he needs you.”

              “I know he does,” Steve said, turning away again.

              “And you need him.  So why…”

              Steve grimaced and dug his fingers into his arm until the pain was nearly unbearable.  He didn’t want to talk about it.  He really didn’t.  But he’d kept the pain inside for days and days, ever since he’d become aware enough to realize how much he couldn’t stand to be touched, ever since the venomous teeth of what this meant had dug into this heart and spread their poison.  It was impossible to ignore or hide it now.  “I can’t…”  His voice failed him, and he shivered, looking down and trying to gather himself.  “I can’t stand having him close.”

              “Why?”  That was asked without judgment.

              Steve glanced over his shoulder at Tony, who hadn’t moved at all.  Who was still sleeping.  And, God, he wanted to go back to bed with him.  He was still so tired, as if the fatigue had settled deep into his organs and bones and couldn’t be expunged no matter how much sleep he got. But the thought of Tony holding onto him, of the nightmares gleefully hissing and dancing on edge of his consciousness…  “It hurts,” he confessed.  “It hurts so much.”

trail.content:
“Steven?”

              Steve ripped around to find Thor behind him.  Seeing their friend in this cramped space, ducking to get inside the area but coming closer so carefully, watching him with worried blue eyes and keeping his distance like he was afraid he might spook an injured animal…  Steve sucked in a shaking breath and wiped wildly at his cheeks.  It took an incredible amount of determination but he calmed himself, too ashamed to do anything else.  He pushed a hand through his hair and hauled in breath after breath until the tiny, shadowy nook stopped spinning and he could focus beyond his skin crawling and his pulse drumming in his ears.

              After what felt like forever, Thor quietly asked, “Are you well, my friend?”

              That was a stupid question.  Steve managed to gather himself more, nodding vigorously before he actually managed to speak. “’m fine,” he mumbled.  The weight of Thor’s gaze felt damning, and he turned before he thought better of it.  He supposed it made sense for Thor to be staring at him as he was, scrutinizing him, but all he could glimpse in the other man’s eyes was grief.  And worry.  And pity.  Steve took another breath, turning back to the shadows.  “I’m fine.  Everythin’s fine.”

              “It does not seem to be.”  Steve felt more than saw Thor take a step closer.  “Nor does it need to be.”

              Steve closed his eyes helplessly.  How could he be so deluded to think he could hide anything?  “We’ll be okay.”  His voice was hardly anything.

              Thor didn’t answer right away, and when he did, the words hurt.  “In time,” he offered quietly, “and with help.  You seem very little like the man I knew four months ago.”  Hearing someone else say that was beyond painful.  In a way, as stressful as it had been being surrounded by these strangers, that had been a shield of sorts, too.  These people, whether it be the Guardians or the Nova Corpsmen or the Xandarian doctors, had never known them before Hell.  They couldn’t see the contrast, so it wasn’t so obvious what had been changed.  What had been lost and damaged.

              Being with Thor was direct evidence of all of that.  The last time Steve had talked to the God of Thunder had been right before the battle where he and Tony had been kidnapped.  Thor had been bickering with Barton over some movie they’d watched, and he’d wanted Steve’s opinion (and for that opinion to match his, of course).  Steve hadn’t ever seen the movie in question, but Thor had been loud and affectionate and cajoling, and they’d all laughed like good buddies.  That had been four months ago.

              Four months.  Four months since they’d been kidnapped.  Four months since they’d been to Earth, to New York.  Four months since he’d been Captain America. In reality, that wasn’t much time at all, but in the pit?  In Hell? The days had gone on and on.  A lifetime of them had passed painfully slowly, moment by moment with so much darkness and so little hope.  “Not sure that I am,” he whispered.

              To that Thor said nothing at first, and the hum of the ship was very loud. Steve could almost hear Tony softly and evenly breathing where the other man still slumbered in the bunk.  At least he’s asleep.  He’s still sleeping.  Steve shivered in relief, rubbing his arms through his shirt and bristling anew at how unpleasant his own touch was.  It was constant, this tickling under his skin like an itch he could never scratch, throbbing in his muscles like pain he couldn’t massage away.  Tears stung his eyes again.  God, he was pathetic.

              Thor sighed.  “I don’t know the particulars of what happened.  I doubt anyone does, aside from you and Stark.  Still, I was told enough about your captivity that my imagination has no difficulty in providing the details.”  Steve closed his eyes tighter. “There is a reason that prisoners of the Kree rarely live to relay their tale.  I can see it you both, signs of the deepest suffering, and I am sorry, truly sorry, that I was not able to find you time.”  Thor’s tone grew taut with anger.  “My father…  He would not permit me to use Asgard’s resources to search for you.  When it became obvious Earthen forces were not going to be nearly sufficient, I returned home and beseeched him for aid. He gave me none and forbid me to spend my time trying to find you.  I defied him, of course, but I wasted precious weeks, and without Heimdall’s aid…” Steve vaguely knew who that was. Thor had mentioned him once or twice before.  Heimdall was his dear friend, the guardian of the Bifrost, someone with the powerful, magical capability of seeing every soul in the galaxy.   If Thor had had his help, if he’d been able to find them right away, before they’d been sold at the slave auction and brought to the moon…

              “I am sorry,” Thor murmured again.

              Steve opened his eyes.  He didn’t turn around.  He didn’t even absolve Thor.  He probably should have, but he just didn’t have the strength.  “Doesn’t matter now,” he finally said as the silence dragged on. summary: Defensive Weapons
title: Defensive Weapons
body:
read it on the AO3 at https://ift.tt/2SdUQAa

by KeelieThompson1

“And if you could?” Tony asked, sounding suddenly intense. “What would you change?”

It was a terrifying question. “If we’d been together,” Steve said softly. “All of us. Listening to each other, planning together, reacting together…either down here or up there…”

“You think it’s that simple?”

Strangely amused, Steve glanced over at him. “You think it’s simple? People uniting completely like that? Even if there isn’t a threat? That’s…that’s the hardest thing in the world.”

summary: Another child
body:
Another child

Peter: pss… uncle wizard 🧙‍♂️

Wong: *sighing* I’m not your uncle Peter.

Peter:…Doctor Dad said you are

Wong: …what is it Peter

Peter: Ned and me need your help with something

Wong:* loosing interest fast* what

Peter whispering into Wong’s ear 👂

Wong evil smile….

Later——————-

Tony: Stephen.. oh god… please I need you to come home

Stephen: I’m on another planet right….

Tony: I Just Gave Birth To Peter!!!

Stephen: …sorry you what?!?!

Tony: *whispering* I just gave birth to Peter

Stephen:🤯😱🥴…how…did…

Tony: IDK 😐… there was this spider pod thing and I touched it and A baby Peter fell out into my hands all slimy… and tiny…. and baby

Stephen: okay… okay don’t move I’m coming as fast as I can

Meanwhile———

(With Peter and Ned)

Ned: hey Peter I don’t think this is working, maybe we should stop

Peter: No, no it’s fine I believe in them

( with Wong)

Rhodey: hey man, what’s up

Wong: you needed to witness this moment in history

Rhodey: …okay…what are we witnessing?

Wong: the greatest Comedy ever to be make

summary: The code
body:
The code

My ticklish boi is back

Peter P, Steve, Bucky, and a lil bit of Tony

Fandom: Marvel

———-

“You think you can handle it?” Tony asked. Peter was tied down in a chair.

“Y-yeah.” He squeaked out as Tony finished strapping him in.

“Okay. Your secret code is 1234. Any questions?” Tony stated.

“1234,” Peter repeated. “Got it! So I’m not allowed to tell them 1234? How long do I have to last?” He asked.

“Just until they get bored.” Tony said as he stood up. “Good luck, kid!” He winked and walked out of the door.

The situation: Peter was tied in a chair. Arms up, legs out, in his spiderman suit. Bucky and Steve would come in and use any tactic they could to get Peter to reveal a secret code. This was just a test that every avenger had to go through. It just so happened to be Peters turn. He was in the middle of a room that had a one way window for Tony to watch him. There was one door and that was the only way out.

The door creaked open and Bucky and Steve walked in, shutting the door behind them. They walked over to where Peter was. Bucky crouched down. He pulled off Peters mask and threw it aside. He got into character.

“So, I understand that there’s a code you need to tell us. What is it?” He interrogated. Steve has to cover his mouth in order to stop his chuckle. Peter remained silent, staring intensly into Buckys eyes.

“We have ways of making you talk. I’ll ask again, what’s the code?” He said, a bit more firm this time. Once again, Peter didn’t say anything. Bucky sighed and stood up. He whispered to Steve for a few seconds before they turned their attention back to Peter. Steve walked over to Peters legs. He mouthed the word ‘sorry’ and he squeezed his thighs. Peter flinched almost so violently that the chair moved. Bucky grinned.

“Well, well, well! Looks like someone’s a bit ticklish.” He teased as he slowly walked towards the boy.

“I won’t tell you anything!” Peter said. Bucky gave him a doubting look and a smug grin before he scratched under his arms. Peter bit his lip and closed his eyes. He arched his back to the best of his abilities but it didn’t dampen the sensation. Steve watched as Bucky’s fingers danced down to Peters ribs and that’s where the spiderman lost it.

“Waiaiait!” He squealed.

“Planning on telling us that code?” Bucky asked as he continued his attack. Peter shook his head, eyes shut, and beaming. Steve’s fingers joined in too. He was squeezing at both of his thighs. Peters reactions would differ depending on certain spots they would tease, scratch, prod, poke, and squeeze. To Peter it was extremely embarrassing. He had two AVENGERS teasing and tickling him into a pile of mush. Not to mention that Tony freaking Stark was spectating through a window. He couldn’t be more humiliated. Steve decided to switch spots and he moved up to Peters neck. This caused him to adorably try and bring up his shoulders to block out the sensation. With the way his arms were bound, it made it nearly impossible to block the neck tickles. He scrunched up his nose and his face turned even pinker than it had already been. Bucky moved down to spider at Parker’s stomach. Seeing as that was his worst spot, he was hysteric.

“I GIHIHIVE!” He screamed. Bucky immediately took his hands off and Steve followed.

“Tell is the code.” Bucky demanded, but he didn’t look to threatening. He was fighting back a smile as he looked at the cute, blushy, panting pile of mush that was sitting before him. Peter didn’t say anything. He just tried to catch his breath. Steve started lightly scratching behind his ears.

“Tell is the code.” He sang teasingly. He was going for more of a good cop.

“8567!” Peter yelped. Both Bucky and Steve knew that wasn’t the right code as Tony had told them what it was before hand.

“Are you sure?” Steve asked as he started moving his hand down to tickle his neck.

“Yes!” He screamed. “Now let me go! I gave you what you want.” Peter said. Steve and Bucky shared a glance and Steve let up.

“Okay. Tony will be in to let you loose.” Steve said, ruffling the boys hair. Steve made his way towards the door and Bucky gave one final scribble on Peters feet and left. Peter was a giggly mess and he desperately tried to regain the ability to breathe. Tony walked in with a proud smile on his face.

“You did it kid.” He said enthusiastically. Peter simply smiled as he continued to pant. Tony walked over and started loosening his restraints.

“Don’t think that I will forget about your little weakness. It’s cute and could be extremely useful for me if I need to get you out of bed or something.” Tony chuckled. As the bondages were released, Peter rubbed his wrists and his ankles. He stood up and grabbed his mask.

“Do I ever get to do this again?” He asked.

“Well you don’t have to- wait… did you say ‘get’? Hold on, did you like this?” Tony beamed. Peter flushed.

“I mean it was fun.” He said, rubbing his neck. Before Tony could reply, Bucky popped his head into the room.

“Hey Tony! We need you.” He called and he slipped away. Tony looked back at Peter, gave him a smile, and walked away.

——-

A/N

blog.name: amethystinawrites
blog.title: Amethystina
blog.description:
An early-thirty something librarian with a fondness for fictional characters, books, video games, movies, and the occasional TV-show.
This is a place for my silly ramblings concerning fanfic writing and how I fail at it. 
I also randomly reblog things.

summary: If you are still doing the mash ups, how would you combine, say, 71. Twenty-Four Hours to Live aaand 49. Arranged Marriage (for...
question: If you are still doing the mash ups, how would you combine, say, 71. Twenty-Four Hours to Live aaand 49. Arranged Marriage (for Winteriron)?
answer:
I admit that I had to think long and hard on this one and, eventually, I ended up with some weird kind of dystopian arranged marriage AU? And it’s not like Bucky will die within twenty-four hours, but his life will certainly be forfeit within a not-to-distant future once those hours are up.

More below the cut!

The story is set in a world that’s a little more technologically advanced than ours. Big parts of the planet has died and people now live in huge, sprawling cities, protected by high walls and various high-tech shields to keep the elements and pollution at bay. Due to how these cities are built (i.e. can’t expand all that easily) the population has to be kept under control. This is done through various methods, like excellent birth control, a limit on children one family can produce, and a firm belief in monogamy and the sanctity of marriage. The one you marry, you stay with for life, because there’s no room to go galavanting off and get kids left and right. The state also has a hand in approving marriages, to make sure that the best genes are preserved. This means that same-sex relationships are, in fact, quite common, since they don’t result in children. But, of course, these couples’ chances of adopting a child are extremely low. Only the rich can pay enough to buy one of the precious babies being allowed to be born each year.

ANYHOW. Like all true dystopian stories, this one has a dark side. Namely that those who aren’t considered beneficial to society are, well, cast out. There are settlements huddled around on the outside of these cities, consisting of the sick, weak, and generally undesirable who have been discreetly shoved out the door. It’s a harsh life since there’s no protection to be had and very little food. More often than not, it’s a death sentence (which, coincidentally, is also the most common punishment for murder, because no one wants to waste precious resources on criminals). There are laws in place to decide who gets to stay or not and, as you might have guessed, they are much harsher for the poor. Anyone who is sick, unmarried, and without a job are more likely to get kicked out.

Bucky is all three.

When he lost his arm four years ago it wasn’t such a big deal at first. Lots of soldiers lose limbs and they’re always given prosthetics to make sure they can keep working (soldiers are, after all, not growing on trees, either). Bucky is no exception. But then, about five months before his thirtieth birthday, he’s suddenly not allowed to extend his contract and finds himself without a job and is given no explanation why. Bucky is a good soldier, but, apparently, the brass has decided he’s not worth it anymore.

Bucky moves in with Steve and Peggy, no longer able to pay for his small one-room apartment, and he realises, quite suddenly, that he is literally months away from getting kicked out. People like him — those with a physical disability, no job, and no spouse — will be shown the door once they’re past thirty. But, naturally, no one wants to give Bucky a job once they find that out. Why hire someone who is nearing their expiration date anyway? And it’s not like he has anyone to marry, either, since he doesn’t qualify for the programs set in place to help people find a suitable match.

So Bucky suddenly finds himself running out of options. Even Steve, who’s been sickly for as long as they both can remember, is safe for now, since he married Peggy. Technically, the state disapproved of that match (Steve doesn’t have very promising genes, they argued) but Peggy pulled enough strings and twisted enough arms to make it happen anyway. Because no one tells Peggy fucking Carter what to do.

Bucky is glad that Steve has a future, but he is admittedly worried about his own. He grows more and more desperate as the weeks past and, long before he’s ready, his birthday arrives. Bucky knows they won’t come for him until the day after, so he has twenty-four hours left before he’s exiled. Both Peggy and Steve are, understandably, distraught while Bucky is mostly numb. He’s done what he can to prepare — bought supplies that will at least last a couple of weeks — but he knows that won’t do much in the long run. Once he’s outside the wall, his fate is sealed.

While he knows that he should spend his last day with his loved ones, he ends up drifting instead. Just walking along the streets, drinking in the city he’s lived in his entire life but will never see again. All their grief and anger just makes his own panic spike. He will go back home before the evening, but, for now, he does what he wants.

Eventually, he ends up at a bar. He figures it’s one of the last times he’ll get to drink, so why not? It’s not a nice place by any means, but the beer is acceptable and the music is good, so he doesn’t complain. 

It’s when he’s just starting to get tipsy that someone bumps into him where he’s sitting hunched over the bar. Bucky turns, annoyed, but the scathing reprimand dies on his lips when his gaze meets a pair of gorgeous brown eyes. The guy is probably a couple of years younger than Bucky but cute as hell with a charming smile and clothes worth more than Bucky’s entire wardrobe. He’s not entirely sure what the guy is doing there — in that kind of bar — but, from the moment their gazes meet, his entire focus shifts to Bucky in an extremely flattering way.

His name is Tony, Bucky learns.

Tony buys Bucky another drink and they get talking. Any other day, Bucky would have made an effort to flirt, but he’s too tired to even try. He even says as much, when Tony seems bewildered at Bucky’s lack of response to his flirting. Without really meaning to, Bucky ends up spilling his life’s story to this virtual stranger, which feels both good and extremely embarrassing. The best part is that Tony genuinely listens, his face growing more and more solemn the more he hears. He asks questions, too, clearly appalled to hear that Bucky is going to kicked out tomorrow.

Tony is clearly too rich to have ever known someone who qualifies to get exiled.

Bucky shows his prosthetic and explains he can’t get a job because of it and, unless someone is willing to marry him within the next eight or nine hours, there’s just nothing to do about it. He tries to smile, but it’s not a very comforting smile.

He knows he’s going to die. He has come to terms with it, no matter how much it hurts. Tony, apparently, has other plans.

He proposes.

Bucky laughs it off at first, assuming it’s a joke, but Tony shakes his head and just repeats the question. Bucky isn’t sure how to react, but, for some reason, what he ends up doing is listing all the reasons why Tony shouldn’t marry him. Tony just smiles and adds some of his own — the fact that he’s already engaged to be married to someone named Sunset Bain (the name tickles at the back of Bucky’s memory but he can’t quite place it), is expected to produce heirs at some point, and would probably give his mentor a heartattack if he suddenly showed up married — but says they don’t matter. 

Bucky argues that they do — divorce isn’t an option. Tony will be stuck with Bucky for life if they get married and he shouldn’t have to do that just to save Bucky’s life. 

Tony argues that there is no better reason. In their day and age, most marriages are arranged anyway, aided by the state and their algorithms and research, and Tony would much rather do something useful with his marriage — like giving Bucky another chance at life.

Besides, they seem to like each other well enough — more than Tony likes his actual fiancée. Bucky might actually be doing Tony a favour by marrying him. They can work out the details later.

It’s not like they’re expected to love each other, but they can make it work.

It takes a lot of arguing before Bucky eventually agrees. Mostly because he realises that he’s being an idiot, saying no to the one thing that can save him from certain death. Steve would never forgive him if he didn’t try.

And that’s how Bucky finds himself at the registration office just before closing, waiting for Steve and Peggy to arrive and serve as witnesses, while his future husband is bribing the clerk to allow their marriage to pass. According to whatever algorithm that decides compatability, they’re a pretty bad match — Bucky is much too poor — but Tony can apparently bypass that just by showing his identification.

Bucky knows that’s probably a bad sign — or a really good one, he hasn’t quite decided — but it’s also a problem for later.

By the time Peggy and Steve arrive, Bucky has gone past nervous and shock and settled for comfortably numb. Sure, he notices the wide-eyed look on Peggy’s face when her gaze lands on Tony — meaning she probably knows who he is — but Tony has already made them all hurry along with the service before she has time to even open her mouth.

And, just like that, Bucky is married.

He and Tony don’t kiss — Bucky is much too awkward for something like that — but Tony gives him a warm, comforting smile and squeezes his hand, and that’s not so bad, either, all things considered.

Then, of course, Peggy asks if Bucky intends to change his last name to Stark, which is when Bucky realises that he’s somehow managed to marry Tony Stark — the heir to one of the biggest, most influential companies in their city and as close to royalty as you can get in their day and age. It’s a bit of a shock, but it’s too late for regrets.

For all intents and purposes, he is now married to Tony Stark.

Bucky has no doubt that he’s going to have an incredibly interesting life from then on out.

—


Aaaand we better end it here. But there’s of course a lot more to be told, like how Bucky and Tony try to fit into each other’s lives and get used to their impulse marriage (and, of course, slowly but surely fall in love for real), plus intrigue caused by Tony’s decision to suddenly break his arranged marriage. You can even throw in Obie and him trying to take over the company, which will be A LOT harder with Bucky there — an experienced, well-trained soldier who is often underestimated just because he happens to have a prosthetic.

It could be a pretty epic story, if you ask me, with politics, action, and a slow burn like you wouldn’t believe.

But this is all you’ll get, at least for now. I hope you like it ;)

I admit that I had to think long and hard on this one and, eventually, I ended up with some weird kind of dystopian arranged marriage AU? And it’s not like Bucky will die within twenty-four hours, but his life will certainly be forfeit within a not-to-distant future once those hours are up.

More below the cut!

[[MORE]]

The story is set in a world that’s a little more technologically advanced than ours. Big parts of the planet has died and people now live in huge, sprawling cities, protected by high walls and various high-tech shields to keep the elements and pollution at bay. Due to how these cities are built (i.e. can’t expand all that easily) the population has to be kept under control. This is done through various methods, like excellent birth control, a limit on children one family can produce, and a firm belief in monogamy and the sanctity of marriage. The one you marry, you stay with for life, because there’s no room to go galavanting off and get kids left and right. The state also has a hand in approving marriages, to make sure that the best genes are preserved. This means that same-sex relationships are, in fact, quite common, since they don’t result in children. But, of course, these couples’ chances of adopting a child are extremely low. Only the rich can pay enough to buy one of the precious babies being allowed to be born each year.

ANYHOW. Like all true dystopian stories, this one has a dark side. Namely that those who aren’t considered beneficial to society are, well, cast out. There are settlements huddled around on the outside of these cities, consisting of the sick, weak, and generally undesirable who have been discreetly shoved out the door. It’s a harsh life since there’s no protection to be had and very little food. More often than not, it’s a death sentence (which, coincidentally, is also the most common punishment for murder, because no one wants to waste precious resources on criminals). There are laws in place to decide who gets to stay or not and, as you might have guessed, they are much harsher for the poor. Anyone who is sick, unmarried, and without a job are more likely to get kicked out.

Bucky is all three.

When he lost his arm four years ago it wasn’t such a big deal at first. Lots of soldiers lose limbs and they’re always given prosthetics to make sure they can keep working (soldiers are, after all, not growing on trees, either). Bucky is no exception. But then, about five months before his thirtieth birthday, he’s suddenly not allowed to extend his contract and finds himself without a job and is given no explanation why. Bucky is a good soldier, but, apparently, the brass has decided he’s not worth it anymore.

Bucky moves in with Steve and Peggy, no longer able to pay for his small one-room apartment, and he realises, quite suddenly, that he is literally months away from getting kicked out. People like him — those with a physical disability, no job, and no spouse — will be shown the door once they’re past thirty. But, naturally, no one wants to give Bucky a job once they find that out. Why hire someone who is nearing their expiration date anyway? And it’s not like he has anyone to marry, either, since he doesn’t qualify for the programs set in place to help people find a suitable match.

So Bucky suddenly finds himself running out of options. Even Steve, who’s been sickly for as long as they both can remember, is safe for now, since he married Peggy. Technically, the state disapproved of that match (Steve doesn’t have very promising genes, they argued) but Peggy pulled enough strings and twisted enough arms to make it happen anyway. Because no one tells Peggy fucking Carter what to do.

Bucky is glad that Steve has a future, but he is admittedly worried about his own. He grows more and more desperate as the weeks past and, long before he’s ready, his birthday arrives. Bucky knows they won’t come for him until the day after, so he has twenty-four hours left before he’s exiled. Both Peggy and Steve are, understandably, distraught while Bucky is mostly numb. He’s done what he can to prepare — bought supplies that will at least last a couple of weeks — but he knows that won’t do much in the long run. Once he’s outside the wall, his fate is sealed.

While he knows that he should spend his last day with his loved ones, he ends up drifting instead. Just walking along the streets, drinking in the city he’s lived in his entire life but will never see again. All their grief and anger just makes his own panic spike. He will go back home before the evening, but, for now, he does what he wants.

Eventually, he ends up at a bar. He figures it’s one of the last times he’ll get to drink, so why not? It’s not a nice place by any means, but the beer is acceptable and the music is good, so he doesn’t complain. 

It’s when he’s just starting to get tipsy that someone bumps into him where he’s sitting hunched over the bar. Bucky turns, annoyed, but the scathing reprimand dies on his lips when his gaze meets a pair of gorgeous brown eyes. The guy is probably a couple of years younger than Bucky but cute as hell with a charming smile and clothes worth more than Bucky’s entire wardrobe. He’s not entirely sure what the guy is doing there — in that kind of bar — but, from the moment their gazes meet, his entire focus shifts to Bucky in an extremely flattering way.

His name is Tony, Bucky learns.

Tony buys Bucky another drink and they get talking. Any other day, Bucky would have made an effort to flirt, but he’s too tired to even try. He even says as much, when Tony seems bewildered at Bucky’s lack of response to his flirting. Without really meaning to, Bucky ends up spilling his life’s story to this virtual stranger, which feels both good and extremely embarrassing. The best part is that Tony genuinely listens, his face growing more and more solemn the more he hears. He asks questions, too, clearly appalled to hear that Bucky is going to kicked out tomorrow.

Tony is clearly too rich to have ever known someone who qualifies to get exiled.

Bucky shows his prosthetic and explains he can’t get a job because of it and, unless someone is willing to marry him within the next eight or nine hours, there’s just nothing to do about it. He tries to smile, but it’s not a very comforting smile.

He knows he’s going to die. He has come to terms with it, no matter how much it hurts. Tony, apparently, has other plans.

He proposes.

Bucky laughs it off at first, assuming it’s a joke, but Tony shakes his head and just repeats the question. Bucky isn’t sure how to react, but, for some reason, what he ends up doing is listing all the reasons why Tony shouldn’t marry him. Tony just smiles and adds some of his own — the fact that he’s already engaged to be married to someone named Sunset Bain (the name tickles at the back of Bucky’s memory but he can’t quite place it), is expected to produce heirs at some point, and would probably give his mentor a heartattack if he suddenly showed up married — but says they don’t matter.

Tony argues that there is no better reason. In their day and age, most marriages are arranged anyway, aided by the state and their algorithms and research, and Tony would much rather do something useful with his marriage — like giving Bucky another chance at life.

Besides, they seem to like each other well enough — more than Tony likes his actual fiancée. Bucky might actually be doing Tony a favour by marrying him. They can work out the details later.

It’s not like they’re expected to love each other, but they can make it work.

It takes a lot of arguing before Bucky eventually agrees. Mostly because he realises that he’s being an idiot, saying no to the one thing that can save him from certain death. Steve would never forgive him if he didn’t try.

And that’s how Bucky finds himself at the registration office just before closing, waiting for Steve and Peggy to arrive and serve as witnesses, while his future husband is bribing the clerk to allow their marriage to pass. According to whatever algorithm that decides compatability, they’re a pretty bad match — Bucky is much too poor — but Tony can apparently bypass that just by showing his identification.

Bucky knows that’s probably a bad sign — or a really good one, he hasn’t quite decided — but it’s also a problem for later.

By the time Peggy and Steve arrive, Bucky has gone past nervous and shock and settled for comfortably numb. Sure, he notices the wide-eyed look on Peggy’s face when her gaze lands on Tony — meaning she probably knows who he is — but Tony has already made them all hurry along with the service before she has time to even open her mouth.

And, just like that, Bucky is married.

He and Tony don’t kiss — Bucky is much too awkward for something like that — but Tony gives him a warm, comforting smile and squeezes his hand, and that’s not so bad, either, all things considered.

Then, of course, Peggy asks if Bucky intends to change his last name to Stark, which is when Bucky realises that he’s somehow managed to marry Tony Stark — the heir to one of the biggest, most influential companies in their city and as close to royalty as you can get in their day and age. It’s a bit of a shock, but it’s too late for regrets.

For all intents and purposes, he is now married to Tony Stark.

Bucky has no doubt that he’s going to have an incredibly interesting life from then on out.

Aaaand we better end it here. But there’s of course a lot more to be told, like how Bucky and Tony try to fit into each other’s lives and get used to their impulse marriage (and, of course, slowly but surely fall in love for real), plus intrigue caused by Tony’s decision to suddenly break his arranged marriage. You can even throw in Obie and him trying to take over the company, which will be A LOT harder with Bucky there — an experienced, well-trained soldier who is often underestimated just because he happens to have a prosthetic.

It could be a pretty epic story, if you ask me, with politics, action, and a slow burn like you wouldn’t believe.

But this is all you’ll get, at least for now. I hope you like it ;)

It takes a lot of arguing before Bucky eventually agrees. Mostly because he realises that he’s being an idiot, saying no to the one thing that can save him from certain death. Steve would never forgive him if he didn’t try.

And that’s how Bucky finds himself at the registration office just before closing, waiting for Steve and Peggy to arrive and serve as witnesses, while his future husband is bribing the clerk to allow their marriage to pass. According to whatever algorithm that decides compatability, they’re a pretty bad match — Bucky is much too poor — but Tony can apparently bypass that just by showing his identification.

Bucky knows that’s probably a bad sign — or a really good one, he hasn’t quite decided — but it’s also a problem for later.

By the time Peggy and Steve arrive, Bucky has gone past nervous and shock and settled for comfortably numb. Sure, he notices the wide-eyed look on Peggy’s face when her gaze lands on Tony — meaning she probably knows who he is — but Tony has already made them all hurry along with the service before she has time to even open her mouth.

And, just like that, Bucky is married.

He and Tony don’t kiss — Bucky is much too awkward for something like that — but Tony gives him a warm, comforting smile and squeezes his hand, and that’s not so bad, either, all things considered.

Then, of course, Peggy asks if Bucky intends to change his last name to Stark, which is when Bucky realises that he’s somehow managed to marry Tony Stark — the heir to one of the biggest, most influential companies in their city and as close to royalty as you can get in their day and age. It’s a bit of a shock, but it’s too late for regrets.

For all intents and purposes, he is now married to Tony Stark.

Bucky has no doubt that he’s going to have an incredibly interesting life from then on out.

—


Aaaand we better end it here. But there’s of course a lot more to be told, like how Bucky and Tony try to fit into each other’s lives and get used to their impulse marriage (and, of course, slowly but surely fall in love for real), plus intrigue caused by Tony’s decision to suddenly break his arranged marriage. You can even throw in Obie and him trying to take over the company, which will be A LOT harder with Bucky there — an experienced, well-trained soldier who is often underestimated just because he happens to have a prosthetic.

It could be a pretty epic story, if you ask me, with politics, action, and a slow burn like you wouldn’t believe.

But this is all you’ll get, at least for now. I hope you like it ;)
trail.content_abstract:
I admit that I had to think long and hard on this one and, eventually, I ended up with some weird kind of dystopian arranged marriage AU? And it’s not like Bucky will die within twenty-four hours, but his life will certainly be forfeit within a not-to-distant future once those hours are up.

More below the cut!
